thread.title: US must accept risks to promote interests: Clinton
thread.title_full: US must accept risks to promote interests: Clinton | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: US must accept risks to promote interests: Clinton
text:
Hillary Clinton, in her opening remarks this morning to a House committee investigating a 2012 fatal terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, will say the US must accept some risks as it looks to promote its interests in a dangerous world.
Mrs Clinton will also say the American government must play a leading role in world affairs despite the threat to diplomatic personnel working overseas, according to a summary of her testimony provided by an aide to her presidential campaign.
Mrs Clinton is making the high-stakes appearance before a Republican-controlled congressional committee that is examining the assault in Benghazi that killed the US ambassador to Libya, Chris Stevens, along with three other Americans.
Her testimony is shaping up to be one of the most consequential moments of her six-month-old presidential campaign.
A strong showing from Mrs Clinton would help her put to rest questions about her actions as secretary of state during the attacks. Should she stumble during the hearing, the Benghazi episode could continue to cast a shadow on her presidential bid, undercutting her argument that she has the judgment and credentials to be commander in chief.
In her statement, Mrs Clinton will make no apologies for sending diplomats to hazardous posts. She will say that Mr. Stevens recognized that diplomats must not hole up in fortified outposts and refuse to engage in global hot spots.
Mrs Clinton's opening remarks suggest a muscular approach to world affairs.
President Barack Obama has faced criticism for "leading from behind," or avoiding entanglements in the Middle East and hesitating to commit military force. Mrs Clinton will use her testimony to sketch a role for the US that is more forward-leaning in its outlook.
